subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA Keyboard layout

messageBody:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
> I understand a bit more now...... I didn't realise that S-SAMPA was
> prescriptive. I realise the value of following a standard, so I guess i
> will just have to get used to the illogicalities - or make my own
> keyboard, which I guess i will have to do!
>

After having thought about the recent SAMPA proposal a bit more, I have
to say I am against it, particularly because of Moira's objections.

After a lengthy, sometimes a bit heated, but overall very productive
discussion, we have concluded that QS is based not on sounds, but on
Lexical sets. Yet the SAMPA proposal suggests basing a keyboard layout
on sounds. The reason for this proposal is good, that we want a uniform
way to discuss QS without having to use contradictory letter names,
numbers, and competing sound charts. I still think we should adopt some
type of standard when discussing letters on this mailing list. In the
one post where such a standard was used, I found it a hundred times
easier to discuss a complicated matter in a simple, straightforward way.

However, I don't think that any of us are actually taking the letters
between the // and pasting them into Word, so we don't need a font with
SAMPA mappings. If we simply agree to use our hacked SAMPA, we can still
discuss letters in a simple, unambiguous way.

But if we insist on mapping the keyboard to SAMPA, we are forcing all
users to conform to an unintuitive way to type, just to please the few
linguists. QS is not an alphabet for linguists; it is supposed to be
natural. Its inventor, Read, took great care that its users should not
have to use extra pen strokes to write. It would be ironic if we violate
that principal when typing QS, making users reach for keys that don't
have any meaning to them just because of the prescriptions of SAMPA,
which has little to do with QS.

Since we think of QS in terms of lexical sets, we should assign
keystrokes accordingly. We should think of it like this:

KIT (If or It in QS) => i
PRICE (I or Ice in QS) => I
Judge => j
Yo-yo => y
FLEECE (Eat in QS) => Y
Ado => a
TRAP (At or Ash in QS) => J

Each of the assignments follows what we are used to typing in TO for
years. "I" gets "I." The "i" in KIT gets "i." The "y" in yo-yo gets "y."
The "a" in the indefinite pronoun gets "a." The letter for FLEECE is a
bit more of a stretch, though we Americans can think of it as the "y" in
"happy." The TRAP letter has no logical connection, but I don't think we
can do anything about that, in the same way we can't do anything about
assigning the letter "R" to CHOICE or "Q" to LOT.

On the other hand, it just seems wrong not to have "I" for "I," "j" for
"j," and "y" for "y." We English speakers have typed these letters for
years this way, and it seems we should continue if we can.

Another reason that SAMPA is inappropriate (as John hinted) is that we
are basing the letters on American pronunciation. Australian speakers
will find the current SAMPA proposal more arbritary than we Americans
do. I say we should have a standard, but we should base the standard on
what is natural.

Paul
